assemblage.title: Polar Coordinates
assemblage.p: The polar coordinates of a point P in the plane are (r, \theta), where

li.p: \abs{r} is the distance from to the pole,
\theta is the angle measured counterclockwise from the polar axis to the ray through P from the pole.

ol.li: Any point with polar coordinates (r, \theta) also has coordinates (r, \theta + 2k\pi), where k is an integer.
The point (r, \theta) can also be designated by (-r, \theta + \pi).
The pole has coordinates (0, \theta), for any value of \theta.
In the polar plane, the coordinate grid lines are circles centered at the pole, with equations r=k, and lines through the pole, with equations \theta = k.

assemblage.title: Conversion Equations

ol.li:
To convert from polar coordinates (r, \theta) to Cartesian:
x \amp = r\cos \theta y \amp = r \sin \theta

assemblage.p: where the choice of \theta depends on the quadrant.

ol.li: To convert an equation from Cartesian to polar coordinates, we replace each x with r\cos \theta and each with y with r\sin \theta. To convert an equation from polar to Cartesian coordinates, look for expressions of the form r\cos \theta,~r\sin \theta,~r^2, or \tan \theta.

When graphing an equation in polar coordinates, we think of sweeping around the pole in the counterclockwise direction, and at each angle \theta the r-value tells us how far the graph is from the pole.
Standard graphs in polar coordinates include circles and roses, cardioids and lima√ßons, lemniscates, and spirals.

To find the intersection points of the polar graphs r=f(\theta) and r=g(\theta) we solve the equation f(\theta)=g(\theta). In addition, we should always check whether the pole is a point on both graphs.

assemblage.title: Imaginary Unit
assemblage.p: We define the imaginary unit, i, by i^2=-1~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~i=\sqrt{-1}

ol.li: The square root of a negative number is an imaginary number: if a \gt 0,~ \sqrt{-a}=i\sqrt{a}
A complex number z is the sum of a real number and an imaginary number, z=a+bi.

We can perform the four arithmetic operations on complex numbers. Operations on Complex Numbers
z_1+z_2=(a+bi)+(c+di)=(a+c)+(b+d)i z_1-z_2=(a+bi)-(c+di)=(a-c)+(b-d)i z_1z_2=(a+bi)(c+di) = (ac-bd)+(ad+bc)i \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} \cdot \dfrac{c-di}{c-di} = \dfrac{ac+bd}{c^2+d^2} + \dfrac{bc-ad}{c^2+d^2}i
The product of a nonzero complex number and its conjugate is always a positive real number. z \bar{z} = (a+bi)(a-bi) = a^2 - b^2i^2 = a^2 - b^2(-1)=a^2+b^2.
We can graph complex numbers in the complex plane.
We can visualize the sum of two complex numbers by vector addition in the complex plane.

assemblage.title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
assemblage.p: Let p(x) be a polynomial of degree n \ge 1. Then p(x) has exactly n complex zeros.

ol.li: The nonreal zeros of a polynomial with real coefficients always occur in conjugate pairs.
Multiplying a complex number by i rotates its graph by 90\degree around the origin.

assemblage.title: Polar Form for a Complex Number
assemblage.p: The complex number z=a+bi can be written in the polar form z=r(\cos\theta+i\sin \theta) where r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} and \theta is defined by a=r \cos \theta,~~~~b=r\sin \theta,~~~~0 \le \theta \le 2\pi The angle \theta is called the argument of the complex number, and r is its length, or modulus.

assemblage.title: Product and Quotient in Polar Form
assemblage.p: If z_1=r(\cos \alpha+i\sin \alpha) and z_2=R(\cos \beta+i\sin \beta), then z_1z_2=rR(\cos (\alpha + \beta) + i \sin (\alpha + \beta)) and \dfrac{z_1}{z_2}=\dfrac{r}{R}(\cos (\alpha - \beta) + i \sin (\alpha - \beta))

assemblage.title: De Moivre's Theorem
assemblage.p: If z=r(\cos\alpha+i\sin \alpha) is a complex number in polar form, and n is a positive integer, then z^n= r^n(\cos n\alpha+i\sin n\alpha)

assemblage.title: Roots of a Complex Number
assemblage.p: A complex number z=r(\cos \alpha + i\sin \alpha) in polar form has n complex nth roots, given by z_k = r^{1/n}\left(\cos \dfrac{\alpha + 2\pi k}{n} + i\sin \dfrac{\alpha + 2\pi k}{n}\right) for k = 0,~1,~2, \cdots,~ n-1.
